channel.title: C++, I need docs
channel.description:
Well I'm going bed now, so could you guys post me some C++ and C docs or anything that will help me learn the syntax of the language?
And learn the language in general. Thanks. I'm really interested.

item.title: C++, I need docs
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Liquid Magic, post:9, topic:384167”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=479929.msg3514361#msg3514361 date=1298837102]

C++ because it supports more tools that will benefit you.

Such as?

If by “tools” you mean features, that doesn’t necessarily mean it’s “better”.
[/quote]
I just cant believe you said “such as”.[/quote]
When I said “such as”, I assumed you were talking about tools i.e. compilers, linkers, profilers/debuggers etc. Then, the line below that, I was just making sure, in case you were talking about language features, you knew that it doesn’t necessarily make a language “better”.

Read full topic

item.title: C++, I need docs
item.dc:creator: @Liquid_Magic Liquid Magic
item.description:
@Liquid_Magic wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:7, topic:384167”][quote author=Liquid Magic link=topic=479929.msg3513793#msg3513793 date=1298789206]
C++ because it supports more tools that will benefit you.
[/quote]
Such as?

If by “tools” you mean features, that doesn’t necessarily mean it’s “better”.[/quote]
I must have given off the wrong message in my post. I didn’t mean to compare them. The OP did. I still use C for the beneficial simplicity and efficiency. I just cant believe you said “such as”.

Read full topic

item.title: C++, I need docs
item.dc:creator: @Kaex Kaex
item.description:
@Kaex wrote:

jmood128:

Any programming language with networking should be able to handle an rsps. It just depends on how well you program it.

Well I’ve wrote a server for the 317 revision in Java using IO, but then decided NIO. And that was great just Java gets boring in some sense. Thanks for that comment though.
I’ll be studying C++ for a long time since you’ve said that lol.

Read full topic

C++ can handle rsps just fine. Your going to see it is better for the back end of the server.

Read full topic

item.title: C++, I need docs
item.dc:creator: @Kaex Kaex
item.description:
@Kaex wrote:

[quote=“Liquid Magic, post:3, topic:384167”][quote author=Kaex link=topic=479929.msg3513630#msg3513630 date=1298779669]

Objective-C is a reflective, object-oriented programming language that adds Smalltalk-style messaging to the C programming language.

Today, it is used primarily on Apple’s Mac OS X and iOS: two environments based on the OpenStep standard, though not compliant with it.[1] Objective-C is the primary language used for Apple’s Cocoa API, and it was originally the main language on NeXT’s NeXTSTEP OS. Generic Objective-C programs that do not use these libraries can also be compiled for any system supported by gcc or Clang.

wxPython is a wrapper for the cross-platform GUI API (often referred to as a ‘toolkit’) wxWidgets (which is written in C++) for the Python programming language. It is one of the alternatives to Tkinter, which is bundled with Python. It is implemented as a Python extension module (native code). Other popular alternatives are PyGTK and PyQt. Like wxWidgets, wxPython is free software.

http://www.cplusplus.com/forum/general/134/

All found via Google, so if it’s wrong info, don’t flame.

When have I ever flamed you lol. Thanks you’ve put me off Python now. I’ll also be staying away from objective-C.
But you never answer’d me, whats betters, c or c++??
[/quote]
C++ because it supports more tools that will benefit you. Learning the basics of I/O is essential if you want to start programming. I won’t be your teacher rather just show you some things. Though I’m no genius; but know enough to do what ever the fuck I want.

You should just buy a book or find an e-tutorial.

Here’s some:

http://cplusplus.com
http://cprogramming.com
http://xoax.net

Those won’t do much but just get you started. You should always be experimenting. MAKE errors; find out what they mean; and make your own strategies to solve them. If you aren’t a problem solver, then you won’t get far.

#include<iostream>
using std::cout;
using std::cin;
using std::endl;

int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
   cout << "hello" << endl;
   return 0;
}

The program above will simply print “hello” to the screen and exit returning 0.

#include<iostream>

The following code is you just using a pre-made library (that uses ACE).

Think of iostream like this (a very fucked up example):

#ifndef _iostream_h_
#define _iostream_h_

obj

#endif

You can make your own:

lib.h

#ifndef _lib_h_
#define _lib_h_

#include<iostream>
using std::cout;
using std::endl;

void do_something();

#endif

lib.cpp

#include"lib.h"

void do_something()
{
   cout << "hi" << endl;
}

There’s your “library” that has a premade function ‘do_something();’ and uses iostream as a backend for IO.

That’s all I want to type because I’m tired.[/quote]

I understand some of the statements like include, worked with that before. And I’m extremely interested in C++, but would it also be good for rsps work? Java just gets a little boring.

Read full topic

item.title: C++, I need docs

item.description:
@Liquid_Magic wrote:

[quote=“Kaex, post:2, topic:384167”][quote author=I Vain I link=topic=479929.msg3513607#msg3513607 date=1298778313]
Objective-C is a reflective, object-oriented programming language that adds Smalltalk-style messaging to the C programming language.

Today, it is used primarily on Apple’s Mac OS X and iOS: two environments based on the OpenStep standard, though not compliant with it.[1] Objective-C is the primary language used for Apple’s Cocoa API, and it was originally the main language on NeXT’s NeXTSTEP OS. Generic Objective-C programs that do not use these libraries can also be compiled for any system supported by gcc or Clang.

wxPython is a wrapper for the cross-platform GUI API (often referred to as a ‘toolkit’) wxWidgets (which is written in C++) for the Python programming language. It is one of the alternatives to Tkinter, which is bundled with Python. It is implemented as a Python extension module (native code). Other popular alternatives are PyGTK and PyQt. Like wxWidgets, wxPython is free software.

http://www.cplusplus.com/forum/general/134/

All found via Google, so if it’s wrong info, don’t flame.
[/quote]

When have I ever flamed you lol. Thanks you’ve put me off Python now. I’ll also be staying away from objective-C.
But you never answer’d me, whats betters, c or c++??[/quote]
C++ because it supports more tools that will benefit you. Learning the basics of I/O is essential if you want to start programming. I won’t be your teacher rather just show you some things. Though I’m no genius; but know enough to do what ever the fuck I want.

You should just buy a book or find an e-tutorial.

Here’s some:

http://cplusplus.com
http://cprogramming.com
http://xoax.net

Those won’t do much but just get you started. You should always be experimenting. MAKE errors; find out what they mean; and make your own strategies to solve them. If you aren’t a problem solver, then you won’t get far.

#include<iostream>
using std::cout;
using std::cin;
using std::endl;

int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
   cout << "hello" << endl;
   return 0;
}

The program above will simply print “hello” to the screen and exit returning 0.

#include<iostream>

The following code is you just using a pre-made library (that uses ACE).

Think of iostream like this (a very fucked up example):

#ifndef _iostream_h_
#define _iostream_h_

obj

#endif

You can make your own:

lib.h

#ifndef _lib_h_
#define _lib_h_

#include<iostream>
using std::cout;
using std::endl;

void do_something();

#endif

lib.cpp

#include"lib.h"

void do_something()
{
   cout << "hi" << endl;
}

There’s your “library” that has a premade function ‘do_something();’ and uses iostream as a backend for IO.

That’s all I want to type because I’m tired.

Read full topic
